sub_topic: Calculation of standard enthalpy change for a reaction involving acids and bases
message_1:
Calculate the standard enthalpy change (in kJ/mol) for the neutralization reaction of hydrochloric acid (HCl) and sodium hydroxide (NaOH) using the following information: 

HCl (aq) + NaOH (aq) → NaCl (aq) + H2O(l)

ΔHf° (kJ/mol): 
HCl (aq) = -167.2 
NaOH (aq) = -469.2 
NaCl (aq) = -407.3 
H2O(l) = -285.8
message_2:
To calculate the standard enthalpy change (ΔH°) for the neutralization reaction, we can use the following equation:

ΔH° = Σ ΔHf°(products) - Σ ΔHf°(reactants)

For the given reaction:

HCl (aq) + NaOH (aq) → NaCl (aq) + H2O(l)

ΔH° = [ΔHf°(NaCl) + ΔHf°(H2O)] - [ΔHf°(HCl) + ΔHf°(NaOH)]

Using the given ΔHf° values:

ΔH° = [(-407.3) + (-285.8)] - [(-167.2) + (-469.2)]

ΔH° = (-693.1) - (-636.4)

ΔH° = -56.7 kJ/mol

The standard enthalpy change for the neutralization reaction of hydrochloric acid and sodium hydroxide is -56.7 kJ/mol.
